issue.body: This ticket tracks overall progress of Python 3.12 support for Numba.

comment.body:
> what's the ETA on this?

Couple of weeks. According to my latest calculations, we are now at 12 errors and 28 failures remaining.

issue.title: Defining variables in Parfors loop break lowering

labels.name: bug - failure to compile
labels.description: Bugs: failed to compile valid code

issue.body:
I discovered the following broken case on main as part of fixing test failures in https://github.com/numba/numba/pull/9255:

```python
from numba import njit, prange

@njit(parallel=True)
def def_in_loop(x):
    c = 0
    for i in prange(x):
        c = i
    return c


r = def_in_loop(10)
print(r) 
```

```pytb

  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 51, in lower_inst
    _lower_parfor_parallel(self, inst)
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 58, in _lower_parfor_parallel
    return _lower_parfor_parallel_std(lowerer, parfor)
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 372, in _lower_parfor_parallel_std
    call_parallel_gufunc(
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 1970, in call_parallel_gufunc
    builder.store(builder.load(only_elem_ptr), lowerer.getvar(k))
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/core/lowering.py", line 1443, in getvar
    assert name not in self._blk_local_varmap
```

Forcing `_disable_sroa_like_opt == True` workaround the issue.

comment.body: This is likely related to mishandling of the SSA variable in parfor code

issue.title: Defining variables in Parfors loop break lowering

labels.name: bug - failure to compile
labels.description: Bugs: failed to compile valid code

issue.body:
I discovered the following broken case on main as part of fixing test failures in https://github.com/numba/numba/pull/9255:

```python
from numba import njit, prange

@njit(parallel=True)
def def_in_loop(x):
    c = 0
    for i in prange(x):
        c = i
    return c


r = def_in_loop(10)
print(r) 
```

```pytb

  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 51, in lower_inst
    _lower_parfor_parallel(self, inst)
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 58, in _lower_parfor_parallel
    return _lower_parfor_parallel_std(lowerer, parfor)
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 372, in _lower_parfor_parallel_std
    call_parallel_gufunc(
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/parfors/parfor_lowering.py", line 1970, in call_parallel_gufunc
    builder.store(builder.load(only_elem_ptr), lowerer.getvar(k))
  File "/path/to/numba/numba/core/lowering.py", line 1443, in getvar
    assert name not in self._blk_local_varmap
```

Forcing `_disable_sroa_like_opt == True` workaround the issue.

issue.title: `njit(parallel=True)` & `prange` are ineffective on Google Colab

labels.name: question
labels.description: Notes an issue as a question

labels.name: performance - run time
labels.description: Performance issue occurring at run time.

issue.body:
## Reporting a bug


- [x] I have tried using the latest released version of Numba (most recent is
 visible in the change log (https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/main/CHANGE_LOG).
- [x] I have included a self contained code sample to reproduce the problem.
  i.e. it's possible to run as 'python bug.py'.



On Google Colab, I installed the latest numba version with `!pip install numba==0.57.1` and wrote a simple script with different versions of the sum function:

```python
import numba
import numpy as np
import time


@numba.njit()
def sum1(A):
    s = 0
    for i in range(A.shape[0]):
        s += A[i]

    return s

@numba.njit(parallel=True)
def sum2(A):
    s = 0
    for i in range(A.shape[0]):
        s += A[i]

    return s

@numba.njit(parallel=True)
def sum3(A):
    s = 0
    for i in numba.prange(A.shape[0]):
        s += A[i]

    return s


def main():
    n_iter = 1000
    size = 100000
    array = np.random.rand(size).astype(np.float32)

    # Complie
    _ = sum1(array)
    _ = sum2(array)
    _ = sum3(array)

    time_start = time.perf_counter()
    for _ in range(n_iter):
        _ = sum1(array)
    delay = time.perf_counter() - time_start
    print(f'sum1 -> {delay}')

    time_start = time.perf_counter()
    for _ in range(n_iter):
        _ = sum2(array)
    delay = time.perf_counter() - time_start
    print(f'sum2 -> {delay}')

    time_start = time.perf_counter()
    for _ in range(n_iter):
        _ = sum3(array)
    delay = time.perf_counter() - time_start
    print(f'sum3 -> {delay}')


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

```

The output is:
```
/usr/local/lib/python3.10/dist-packages/numba/core/typed_passes.py:334: NumbaPerformanceWarning: 
The keyword argument 'parallel=True' was specified but no transformation for parallel execution was possible.

To find out why, try turning on parallel diagnostics, see https://numba.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user/parallel.html#diagnostics for help.

File "test.py", line 15:
@numba.njit(parallel=True)
def sum2(A):
^

  warnings.warn(errors.NumbaPerformanceWarning(msg,
sum1 -> 0.15685234400007175
sum2 -> 0.15303947399979734
sum3 -> 0.1608453680000821
```

No acceleration is achieved whatsoever. Running `!numba -s` produces the following:

```
__Time Stamp__
Report started (local time)                   : 2023-10-25 21:40:52.960064
UTC start time                                : 2023-10-25 21:40:52.960071
Running time (s)                              : 2.334814

__Hardware Information__
Machine                                       : x86_64
CPU Name                                      : broadwell
CPU Count                                     : 2
Number of accessible CPUs                     : 2
List of accessible CPUs cores                 : 0 1
CFS Restrictions (CPUs worth of runtime)      : None

CPU Features                                  : 64bit adx aes avx avx2 bmi bmi2
                                                cmov cx16 cx8 f16c fma fsgsbase
                                                fxsr invpcid lzcnt mmx movbe
                                                pclmul popcnt prfchw rdrnd rdseed
                                                rtm sahf sse sse2 sse3 sse4.1
                                                sse4.2 ssse3 xsave xsaveopt

Memory Total (MB)                             : 12982
Memory Available (MB)                         : 12004

__OS Information__
Platform Name                                 : Linux-5.15.120+-x86_64-with-glibc2.35
Platform Release                              : 5.15.120+
OS Name                                       : Linux
OS Version                                    : #1 SMP Wed Aug 30 11:19:59 UTC 2023
OS Specific Version                           : ?
Libc Version                                  : glibc 2.35

__Python Information__
Python Compiler                               : GCC 11.4.0
Python Implementation                         : CPython
Python Version                                : 3.10.12
Python Locale                                 : en_US.UTF-8

__Numba Toolchain Versions__
Numba Version                                 : 0.56.4
llvmlite Version                              : 0.39.1

__LLVM Information__
LLVM Version                                  : 11.1.0

__CUDA Information__
CUDA Device Initialized                       : False
CUDA Driver Version                           : ?
CUDA Runtime Version                          : ?
CUDA NVIDIA Bindings Available                : ?
CUDA NVIDIA Bindings In Use                   : ?
CUDA Detect Output:
None
CUDA Libraries Test Output:
None

__NumPy Information__
NumPy Version                                 : 1.23.5
NumPy Supported SIMD features                 : ('MMX', 'SSE', 'SSE2', 'SSE3', 'SSSE3', 'SSE41', 'POPCNT', 'SSE42', 'AVX', 'F16C', 'FMA3', 'AVX2')
NumPy Supported SIMD dispatch                 : ('SSSE3', 'SSE41', 'POPCNT', 'SSE42', 'AVX', 'F16C', 'FMA3', 'AVX2', 'AVX512F', 'AVX512CD', 'AVX512_KNL', 'AVX512_KNM', 'AVX512_SKX', 'AVX512_CLX', 'AVX512_CNL', 'AVX512_ICL')
NumPy Supported SIMD baseline                 : ('SSE', 'SSE2', 'SSE3')
NumPy AVX512_SKX support detected             : False

__SVML Information__
SVML State, config.USING_SVML                 : False
SVML Library Loaded                           : False
llvmlite Using SVML Patched LLVM              : True
SVML Operational                              : False

__Threading Layer Information__
TBB Threading Layer Available                 : True
+-->TBB imported successfully.
OpenMP Threading Layer Available              : True
+-->Vendor: GNU
Workqueue Threading Layer Available           : True
+-->Workqueue imported successfully.

__Numba Environment Variable Information__
None found.

__Conda Information__
Conda not available.
```

Approximately a year ago, numba was functioning correctly on Colab. However, since then multiple changes have been applied including a python version upgrade.

comment.body: This is more likely a problem of the kind of CPU cores provisioned by Colab. If the 2 CPU cores are actually hyperthreaded cores, there are only one physical core. Therefore, you do not actually get parallel execution, but there are overhead from Numba to schedule the work over multi-cores.

pull_request.title: Fix SSA to consider variables whose use is not dominated by the definition
pull_request.body:
Fix #9242. 

<!--

Thanks for wanting to contribute to Numba :)

First, if you need some help or want to chat to the core developers, please
visit https://gitter.im/numba/numba for real time chat or post to the Numba
forum https://numba.discourse.group/.

Here's some guidelines to help the review process go smoothly.

0. Please write a description in this text box of the changes that are being
   made.

1. Please ensure that you have written units tests for the changes made/features
   added.

2. If you are closing an issue please use one of the automatic closing words as
   noted here: https://help.github.com/articles/closing-issues-using-keywords/

3. If your pull request is not ready for review but you want to make use of the
   continuous integration testing facilities here, please click the arrow besides
   "Create Pull Request" and choose "Create Draft Pull Request".
   When it's ready for review, you can click the button "ready to review" near
   the end of the pull request
   (besides "This pull request is still a work in progress".)
   The maintainers will then be automatically notified to review it.

4. Once review has taken place please do not add features or make changes out of
   the scope of those requested by the reviewer (doing this just add delays as
   already reviewed code ends up having to be re-reviewed/it is hard to tell
   what is new etc!). Further, please do not rebase your branch on main/force
   push/rewrite history, doing any of these causes the context of any comments
   made by reviewers to be lost. If conflicts occur against main they should
   be resolved by merging main into the branch used for making the pull
   request.

Many thanks in advance for your cooperation!

-->

issue.title: File output within njit
issue.body:
Hi all, I've been using numba for several physics-based applications and it is amazing. I have a feature request that I think could be quite useful (feel free to remove this request if this is not the best place). So I would like to be able to print to files within njitted functions, which is very often done for logging in numerical codes. I am aware that this is possible using the "with objmode" approach, but ideally I would not need to escape back to python intepreter if I am printing in  a loop or something. 

So, what I would like to be able to do is something like this:

```python
@njit
def f(x):
    file = open('test.txt', 'w')
    res = x * 2.0 # some computation
    file.write(f"result = {res}") 
    file.close()

``` 

I have tried hacking together something with printf in c and ctypes, but numba does not understand ctypes "c_char_p" and the file has to be reopened everytime, so this not really feasible. I also tried just redirecting numba output, but this seems to have some significant performance overhead.

Thanks very much for all the work that you all do.

comment.body:
Have you tried best practices?
logger.info(f'result = {res}')

issue.title: `njit(parallel=True)` & `prange` are ineffective on Google Colab
issue.body:

issue.title: File output within njit
issue.body:
Hi all, I've been using numba for several physics-based applications and it is amazing. I have a feature request that I think could be quite useful (feel free to remove this request if this is not the best place). So I would like to be able to print to files within njitted functions, which is very often done for logging in numerical codes. I am aware that this is possible using the "with objmode" approach, but ideally I would not need to escape back to python intepreter if I am printing in  a loop or something. 

So, what I would like to be able to do is something like this:

```python
@njit
def f(x):
    file = open('test.txt', 'w')
    res = x * 2.0 # some computation
    file.write(f"result = {res}") 
    file.close()

``` 

I have tried hacking together something with printf in c and ctypes, but numba does not understand ctypes "c_char_p" and the file has to be reopened everytime, so this not really feasible. I also tried just redirecting numba output, but this seems to have some significant performance overhead.

Thanks very much for all the work that you all do.

comment.body: I think it requires too much work and too little to gain in bypassing the Python interpreter for file I/O. But exposing unicode strings in Numba to `c_char_p` is actually worth doing for folks who want to call out to their custom C code for I/O.

issue.title: @vectorize-decorated functions are not found by sphinx

labels.name: good second issue
labels.description: A good issue for second time contributors

issue.body:
- [x] I am using the latest released version of Numba (most recent is visible in
 the change log (https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/master/CHANGE_LOG).
- [ ] I have included below a minimal working reproducer (if you are unsure how
 to write one see http://matthewrocklin.com/blog/work/2018/02/28/minimal-bug-reports).

I use `sphinx` with the `apidoc` extension to have a reference documentation generated automatically.
For functions decorated with `njit` this works without any complications, for `vectorize` however, the function disappears from the docs, indicating that apidoc either cannot find it or decides not to include it. (Sorry for the lack of better info).

Since this is sphinx related I am not sure how to include a minimal example, but if it would help and I find some time I can try to set up a mini-repository.

comment.body:
Hello @HPLegion ,
thanks for responding. The issue only arises whenever I add the extra extension in the `conf.py`. Otherwise the documentation builds fine without warnings, except that the module functions are not present (see below)

![image](https://github.com/numba/numba/assets/18087952/62e7ded3-caac-4a1e-93e5-e25c5cb55686)
 
![image](https://github.com/numba/numba/assets/18087952/e3371f2e-f34c-453b-99f2-f4fb16e4c3fb)

The `conf.py` with the extension looks like :

```python
import os
import sys

import sarkas

sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath("../sarkas"))
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath("../sarkas/time_evolution"))
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath("../sarkas/utilities"))
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath("../sarkas/potentials"))
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath("../sarkas/tools"))
sys.path.insert(0, os.path.abspath("./_ext"))        # <-------- this is where the extension file is located

extensions = [
    "sphinx.ext.napoleon",  
    "sphinx.ext.autodoc",  
    "sphinx.ext.autosummary", 
    "numbadecoratordoc"                  # <-------- how i called the file
]

# ... more stuff ...


autodoc_mock_imports = ["yaml", "numba", "scipy", "optparse", "time", "pyfftw", "pyfiglet", "tqdm", "fmm3dpy"]

# Generate the API documentation when building
autosummary_generate = True
autosummary_generate_overwrite = True
# # A list of ignored prefixes for module index sorting.
modindex_common_prefix = ["sarkas."]

# Make sure the target is unique
autosectionlabel_prefix_document = True

# Napoleon settings
napoleon_google_docstring = False
napoleon_numpy_docstring = True
napoleon_include_init_with_doc = False
napoleon_include_private_with_doc = False
napoleon_include_special_with_doc = True
napoleon_use_admonition_for_examples = False
napoleon_use_admonition_for_notes = False
napoleon_use_admonition_for_references = False
napoleon_use_ivar = True
napoleon_use_param = False
napoleon_use_rtype = False
```

issue.title: Named argument parsing for jit decorated functions does not match Python 3.10

labels.name: bug - miscompile
labels.description: Bugs: miscompile

labels.name: bug - failure to compile
labels.description: Bugs: failed to compile valid code

issue.body:
Numba 0.58.1 and `main` does not parse named arguments correctly when compared to Python 3.10.

Reproducer:

```python

import numba

def bar(a, b, c,*args, named_arg=None):
    print(a, b, c)
    print("Args:", args)
    print("Named_arg", named_arg)

foo = numba.jit(bar)
```

The issue manifests in at least two ways:

a) Numba parses the named argument following `*args` in the incorrect manner. 

```
foo(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
bar(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

# Output from foo
# 1 2 3
# Args: 4
# Named_arg 5
#
# Output from bar
# 1 2 3
# Args: (4, 5)
# Named_arg None
```
b) Raises a `TypeError` incorrectly

```python
bar(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, named_arg=6)
foo(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, named_arg=6)

# Output from bar
# 1 2 3
# Args: (4, 5)
# Named_arg 6
#
# Output from foo 
#    foo(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, named_arg=6)
# TypeError: too many arguments: expected 5, got 6

```

The issue happens due to the way arguments are parsed in the `numba.core.dispatcher` module: https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/main/numba/core/dispatcher.py#L261-L269 and then the matching of named args is done in https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/452eb5755320506de96bed83021566d0093a3d3a/numba/_dispatcher.cpp#L790

comment.body:
> Some relevant issues / PRs I stumbled across:
> 
>     * [Compilation failure when overload contains *args and multiple keyword arguments #5291](https://github.com/numba/numba/issues/5291)
> 
>     * [fix argument binding with var positional and kwargs #5292](https://github.com/numba/numba/pull/5292)
> 
>     * [*args Issue Tracking Megathread #8108](https://github.com/numba/numba/issues/8108)

Thanks for the references. I was only looking at the dispatcher, seems there are other places in the typing layer of Numba that need to be fixed as well.

issue.title: @vectorize-decorated functions are not found by sphinx

labels.name: good second issue
labels.description: A good issue for second time contributors

issue.body:
- [x] I am using the latest released version of Numba (most recent is visible in
 the change log (https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/master/CHANGE_LOG).
- [ ] I have included below a minimal working reproducer (if you are unsure how
 to write one see http://matthewrocklin.com/blog/work/2018/02/28/minimal-bug-reports).

I use `sphinx` with the `apidoc` extension to have a reference documentation generated automatically.
For functions decorated with `njit` this works without any complications, for `vectorize` however, the function disappears from the docs, indicating that apidoc either cannot find it or decides not to include it. (Sorry for the lack of better info).

Since this is sphinx related I am not sure how to include a minimal example, but if it would help and I find some time I can try to set up a mini-repository.

comment.body:
@SilvestriStefano 

Hi,

unfortunately, it has been a while since I have thought about this, so it is a bit tricky to give good advice. However: Those errors do not look like sphinx problems. It looks like there is actually a problem with the package you are documenting. If you run a pure Python shell in the environment that you build the documentation with, can you actually import that package as expected or do you get a similar error?

Cheers

issue.title: Named argument parsing for jit decorated functions does not match Python 3.10

labels.name: bug - miscompile
labels.description: Bugs: miscompile

labels.name: bug - failure to compile
labels.description: Bugs: failed to compile valid code

issue.body:
Numba 0.58.1 and `main` does not parse named arguments correctly when compared to Python 3.10.

Reproducer:

```python

import numba

def bar(a, b, c,*args, named_arg=None):
    print(a, b, c)
    print("Args:", args)
    print("Named_arg", named_arg)

foo = numba.jit(bar)
```

The issue manifests in at least two ways:

a) Numba parses the named argument following `*args` in the incorrect manner. 

```
foo(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)
bar(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)

# Output from foo
# 1 2 3
# Args: 4
# Named_arg 5
#
# Output from bar
# 1 2 3
# Args: (4, 5)
# Named_arg None
```
b) Raises a `TypeError` incorrectly

```python
bar(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, named_arg=6)
foo(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, named_arg=6)

# Output from bar
# 1 2 3
# Args: (4, 5)
# Named_arg 6
#
# Output from foo 
#    foo(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, named_arg=6)
# TypeError: too many arguments: expected 5, got 6

```

The issue happens due to the way arguments are parsed in the `numba.core.dispatcher` module: https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/main/numba/core/dispatcher.py#L261-L269 and then the matching of named args is done in https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/452eb5755320506de96bed83021566d0093a3d3a/numba/_dispatcher.cpp#L790

comment.body:
Some relevant issues / PRs I stumbled across:

* #5291 
* #5292 
* #8108

issue.title: M1 LLVM Runtimedyld Invalid page reloc value assertion error

labels.name: llvm
labels.description: LLVM related issues

labels.name: ISA: ARM
labels.description: Issue related to ARM ISA

labels.name: bug - segfault
labels.description: Bugs that cause SIGSEGV, SIGABRT, SIGILL, SIGBUS

issue.body:
We are seeing a LLVM Assertion error occurring randomly in our build farm.

The error message is:

```
Assertion failed: (isInt<33>(Addend) && "Invalid page reloc value."), function encodeAddend, file /path/to/conda-bld/llvmdev_1643905487494/work/lib/ExecutionEngine/RuntimeDyld/Targets/RuntimeDyldMachOAArch64.h, line 210
```

Earliest report is from [gitter on July 15, 2022](https://matrix.to/#/!gFwSEpcuaweltInwDW:gitter.im/$FF4q0-XAu9Dogzf42oblpG9_IYwUcOxg42RSYdP-or0?via=gitter.im&via=matrix.org&via=tryp.io)

The error can be triggered with the below script on [bdb2384](https://github.com/numba/numba/commit/bdb238410946f5ef26c83629f36b5ec3cc6cf336). The error usually occurs within 10 iteration.

```
!python setup.py build_ext --inplace 
c = 0
_exit_code = 0
tests = """
numba.tests.test_stencils.TestManyStencils.test_basic40
numba.tests.test_stencils.TestManyStencils.test_basic70
numba.tests.test_array_constants.TestConstantArray.test_too_big_to_freeze
numba.tests.test_array_manipulation.TestArrayManipulation.test_fill_diagonal_basic
""".split()
cmdarg = ' '.join(tests)
while _exit_code == 0 and c < 150:
    print(f"c={c}".center(80, '='))
    !NUMBA_OPT=0 python -m unittest -vb $cmdarg $cmdarg
    c += 1
    print(f"exit={_exit_code}")
    assert _exit_code == 0
```
The error occurs in both LLVM 11 and LLVM 14. 

The current hypothesis is that the LLVM Runtimedyld is mishandling far jumps. To relate this to the reproducer above, the situation can be created by:

- first JITing some stencil kernels, which tend to be large and esp. larger when OPT=0
- allocating large amount of memory as in `test_too_big_to_freeze` (the compilation and execution bits in the tests can be commented out and it will still trigger the error)
- JITing more array operations as in `test_fill_diagonal_basic`. The assertion error occurs here. The guess is that JITed code emitted for the stencil tests are reused here. The large allocation in between help make sure there is a gap/fragmentation in the memory space such that the fill_diagonal functions are JITed in somewhere far away.

Julia devs is pointing to a broken large code model in LLVM Runtimedyld for MachO aarch64. See https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/42295#issuecomment-1008427270, https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/43664.

comment.body: @PhilipVinc Thanks - indeed, that was a Numba limitation. I think in #9001 and https://github.com/gmarkall/numba-issue-9001 we're getting close to a really good reproducer now, so there's probably no need for additional testing here - thanks for everything you've looked into so far :-)

issue.title: Docs should be updated for CUDA 12

labels.name: CUDA
labels.description: CUDA related issue/PR

issue.body:
The [current installation docs](https://numba.pydata.org/numba-doc/latest/cuda/overview.html#software) only mention `cudatoolkit` should be installed. However, CUDA 12 changes the way packages are organized and Numba should now require `cuda-nvcc=12.x` and I believe `cuda-version=12.x` too. Particularly, without `cuda-nvcc=12.x` installed, one might encounter errors such as:

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 7, in <module>
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/cuda/cudadrv/runtime.py", line 111, in get_version
    self.cudaRuntimeGetVersion(ctypes.byref(rtver))
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/cuda/cudadrv/runtime.py", line 65, in __getattr__
    self._initialize()
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/cuda/cudadrv/runtime.py", line 51, in _initialize
    self.lib = open_cudalib('cudart')
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/cuda/cudadrv/libs.py", line 63, in open_cudalib
    path = get_cudalib(lib)
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/cuda/cudadrv/libs.py", line 55, in get_cudalib
    libdir = get_cuda_paths()[dir_type].info
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/cuda/cuda_paths.py", line 223, in get_cuda_paths
    'nvvm': _get_nvvm_path(),
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/cuda/cuda_paths.py", line 201, in _get_nvvm_path
    candidates = find_lib('nvvm', path)
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/misc/findlib.py", line 44, in find_lib
    return find_file(regex, libdir)
  File "/opt/conda/envs/test/lib/python3.10/site-packages/numba/misc/findlib.py", line 56, in find_file
    entries = os.listdir(ldir)
FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/opt/conda/envs/test/nvvm/lib64'
```

cc @jakirkham @gmarkall

comment.body:
> Currently missing are `cuda-cudart` ( https://github.com/conda-forge/cuda-cudart-feedstock/issues/1 ) and as a consequence `cuda-nvcc-impl` ( https://github.com/conda-forge/cuda-nvcc-impl-feedstock/issues/3 )

Both of these have since been added on Windows. We could use some help testing them though. Would appreciate hearing any feedback

issue.title: Support set(<type>) in numba typed dictionaries?
issue.body:
Hi! I am playing around with getting dask to scale to a large number of input partitions (>200k) on large task graphs (> 5k layers).
I've almost got it but the missing piece is being able to return a dict that has values which are sets.

Right now part of the solution looks like:
```python3
import numba as nb

_coords_kernel_input_type = nb.types.Set(nb.types.UniTuple(nb.types.int64, 1), reflected=True)
_coords_kernel_keyval_type = nb.types.Tuple([nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.int64])
_coords_kernel_return_type = nb.types.DictType(
    _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
    _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
)

@nb.jit(_coords_kernel_return_type(_coords_kernel_input_type, nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.unicode_type), nopython=True)
def _coords_single_input_kernel(output_blocks, output_key, index_key):
    output = nb.typed.Dict.empty(
        _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
        _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
    )
    for out_coord in output_blocks:
        output[(output_key, out_coord[0])] = (index_key, out_coord[0])
    return output
```

The real solution would look like:
```python3
import numba as nb

_coords_kernel_input_type = nb.types.Set(nb.types.UniTuple(nb.types.int64, 1), reflected=True)
_coords_kernel_keyval_type = nb.types.Tuple([nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.int64])
_coords_kernel_return_type = nb.types.DictType(
    _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
    nb.types.Set(_coords_kernel_keyval_type),
)

@nb.jit(_coords_kernel_return_type(_coords_kernel_input_type, nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.unicode_type), nopython=True)
def _coords_single_input_kernel(output_blocks, output_key, index_key):
    output = nb.typed.Dict.empty(
        _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
        nb.types.Set(_coords_kernel_keyval_type),
    )
    for out_coord in output_blocks:
        output[(output_key, out_coord[0])] = {(index_key, out_coord[0])}
    return output
```

But right now that raises an exception because sets and lists are not allow within dicts due to this sentry: https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/main/numba/core/types/containers.py#L719

comment.body: I had some other things take priority over this but I definitely still have a use case for it (optimization passes of very large task graphs in dask). I'd like to see this available as well!

issue.title: Support set(<type>) in numba typed dictionaries?
issue.body:
Hi! I am playing around with getting dask to scale to a large number of input partitions (>200k) on large task graphs (> 5k layers).
I've almost got it but the missing piece is being able to return a dict that has values which are sets.

Right now part of the solution looks like:
```python3
import numba as nb

_coords_kernel_input_type = nb.types.Set(nb.types.UniTuple(nb.types.int64, 1), reflected=True)
_coords_kernel_keyval_type = nb.types.Tuple([nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.int64])
_coords_kernel_return_type = nb.types.DictType(
    _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
    _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
)

@nb.jit(_coords_kernel_return_type(_coords_kernel_input_type, nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.unicode_type), nopython=True)
def _coords_single_input_kernel(output_blocks, output_key, index_key):
    output = nb.typed.Dict.empty(
        _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
        _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
    )
    for out_coord in output_blocks:
        output[(output_key, out_coord[0])] = (index_key, out_coord[0])
    return output
```

The real solution would look like:
```python3
import numba as nb

_coords_kernel_input_type = nb.types.Set(nb.types.UniTuple(nb.types.int64, 1), reflected=True)
_coords_kernel_keyval_type = nb.types.Tuple([nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.int64])
_coords_kernel_return_type = nb.types.DictType(
    _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
    nb.types.Set(_coords_kernel_keyval_type),
)

@nb.jit(_coords_kernel_return_type(_coords_kernel_input_type, nb.types.unicode_type, nb.types.unicode_type), nopython=True)
def _coords_single_input_kernel(output_blocks, output_key, index_key):
    output = nb.typed.Dict.empty(
        _coords_kernel_keyval_type,
        nb.types.Set(_coords_kernel_keyval_type),
    )
    for out_coord in output_blocks:
        output[(output_key, out_coord[0])] = {(index_key, out_coord[0])}
    return output
```

But right now that raises an exception because sets and lists are not allow within dicts due to this sentry: https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/main/numba/core/types/containers.py#L719

comment.body: Any updates on this? support for typed sets would be amazing!

issue.title: @vectorize-decorated functions are not found by sphinx

labels.name: good second issue
labels.description: A good issue for second time contributors

issue.body:
- [x] I am using the latest released version of Numba (most recent is visible in
 the change log (https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/master/CHANGE_LOG).
- [ ] I have included below a minimal working reproducer (if you are unsure how
 to write one see http://matthewrocklin.com/blog/work/2018/02/28/minimal-bug-reports).

I use `sphinx` with the `apidoc` extension to have a reference documentation generated automatically.
For functions decorated with `njit` this works without any complications, for `vectorize` however, the function disappears from the docs, indicating that apidoc either cannot find it or decides not to include it. (Sorry for the lack of better info).

Since this is sphinx related I am not sure how to include a minimal example, but if it would help and I find some time I can try to set up a mini-repository.

comment.body:
Hello all,
I am adjusting/improving/cleaning up the documentation ([pr#160](https://github.com/murillo-group/sarkas/pull/60)) for a python package. However, I have been struggling with documenting jit-decorated functions. I am using `autosummary` extension to generate recursively a page for every module/class/function (see [SO#2701998](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2701998/automatically-document-all-modules-recursively-with-sphinx-autodoc/62613202#62613202) )

I have tried all the solutions mentioned here:

- Adding `os.environ["NUMBA_DISABLE_JIT"] = '1'` to the `conf.py` does nothing ;
- the autodoc extensions by @HPLegion, @gipert, @guilhermeleobas all return warnings and errors like  the following
```shell
WARNING: [autosummary] failed to import sarkas.potentials.
Possible hints:
* AttributeError: module 'sarkas' has no attribute 'potentials'
* ImportError:
* TypeError: Failed in nopython mode pipeline (step: nopython frontend)
```
and/or
```shell
Failed to import sarkas.potentials.
Possible hints:
* AttributeError: module 'sarkas' has no attribute 'potentials'
* TypeError: Failed in nopython mode pipeline (step: nopython frontend)
issubclass() arg 2 must be a class or tuple of classes
```
Somehow it can't read the submodules anymore?

I am using Sphinx v4.5.0, but I have also tried Sphinx v6.2.1 and  v7.2.6 with the same results. 

I don't really understand what I am doing wrong any help is highly appreciated.

issue.title: File output within njit
issue.body:
Hi all, I've been using numba for several physics-based applications and it is amazing. I have a feature request that I think could be quite useful (feel free to remove this request if this is not the best place). So I would like to be able to print to files within njitted functions, which is very often done for logging in numerical codes. I am aware that this is possible using the "with objmode" approach, but ideally I would not need to escape back to python intepreter if I am printing in  a loop or something. 

So, what I would like to be able to do is something like this:

`
@njit
def f(x):
 file = open('test.txt', 'w')
 for i in range(10): 
  res += x[i] 
  file.write(f"temp. result = {res}") 
 file.close()

` 

I have tried hacking together something with printf in c and ctypes, but numba does not understand ctypes "c_char_p" and the file has to be reopened everytime, so this not really feasible. I also tried just redirecting numba output, but this seems to have some significant performance overhead.

Thanks very much for all the work that you all do.
